text: for more than a quarter century jay
mcinerney has been one of the most
conspicuous and productive fiction
writers of his generation best known for
novels like bright lights big city and
brightness Falls McInerney is also an
accomplished short story writer and he
has a new collection it's called how it
ended and the title implies that
McInerney who for so long has been a
laureate of Manhattan and its ups and
downs has returned to his subject at a
time when the city is in a different
place from where it was some years ago
recently Jay McInerney visited The Times
and he and I talked about the art of a
short story the demands of the novel and
the changing landscape of a city he
loves Jay McInerney you are best known
as a novelist but you've brought out a
collection of short stories how it ended
that actually covers the whole of what's
now become a long and quite productive
career why did you decide to do this at
this time what you know like most
novelists I cut my teeth writing short
stories you don't suddenly at the age of
21 or to decide to sit down and write a
novel and I also studied with to the
great masters of the forum when I went
to Syracuse University for for graduate
school Raymond Carver and Tobias Wolff
were my teachers there and I decided
that I wanted to really see if I could
write a collection of short stories and
once I sat down I wrote a burst of a
dozen short story isn't it and probably
six months and my editor suggested that
I include the stories that I've
published earlier in my career in
magazines and in between my novels and
it it turned out that you know there was
a good 15 or 20 stories that I'd
published in the meantime I'd always
been daunted by the short story form at
the same time I've always loved it and
now what's especially daunting about it
is it that it's so compressed that you
have to get everything right in a short
story yes I think that's pretty much it
is that you know
the novel is very forgiving it can have
digression zit can have false starts
that can have you know it can even have
patches of god forbid undistinguished
prose and you know the short story has
to burn with that hard gem-like flame i
think i don't think that you know it has
to have a great economy of means you
know I think that there are those rare
writers like John Updike perhaps Richard
Ford who seemed to be almost
ambidextrous who who are good in both
forms but so many people like Carver
like Frank O'Connor or like most of the
novelists we can name just seem to
naturally be drawn to one or the other
and I was I was afraid that I was a
novelist for better or worse I mean I
guess you shouldn't complain about being
a novelist you're a very celebrated
writer you've been famous really from
very early age your late 20s but I don't
think many people know much about you
aside from the the public persona where
are you from where did you grow up
what's your background yeah I guess
there's a sense in which I didn't exist
until I was 29 but I I was kind my
father was a corporate gypsy and my
family is from the Boston area wells in
Newton we were a fairly observant Irish
Catholic household and you know I
couldn't imagine following my father
into you know into the corporate world
are you a New Yorker is that how you see
yourself oh absolutely yeah and and you
know I I mean I didn't have the I didn't
have the good fortune to be born here
but I had the good sense to move here
and you know I I don't I don't give
people a lot of credit for for being
born here I came to New York at a moment
when it could have almost gone either
way
19 you know fall of 1979 beginning of
the 1980s New York was just recovering
then but there was a moment when people
had really written written the city off
and and I watched the I watched the
prosperity the growing prosperity the
eighties with a with a kind of sense of
disbelief I mean I think is an
irish-catholic I always thinks things
will go wrong sooner or later but let's
talk about the world falling apart the
way that's been one of your themes for a
long time now
you have two brilliant interrelated
novels brightness falls and then the
good life they feature a couple Russell
and Corinne Calloway who seemed to be
very glamorous Manhattanites but
actually they're not they're kind of
scraping by their apartments too small
there is some of that older story of the
Stryver in your fiction right because
people think of the aristocrats and in
my mind all my characters are strivers I
feel it in recent years I've had to deal
with the perception that I'm writing
about extremely prosperous and even
wealthy people and and in fact it seems
to me that most of my characters are the
typical character like Russell and
Corinne Callaway these are people who
are renting a loft downtown and sort of
clinging clinging to this Manhattan
existence which is just almost out of
their reach and you know I the one hand
they're their life is I guess somewhat
glamorous in the way that I think the
city is glamorous but they you know
they're not but at the same time they're
they're struggling to maintain their
their foothold in the city and I hope
that Manhattan will always be a place
that that has room for people who with
with artistic ambitions with people who
aren't making seven figures a year and
when I came to this city it was it was a
city of Bohemians and it was a city of
punk rock and and and graffiti artists
and hip-hop was being invented here and
independent filmmakers were reinventing
the cinema and and these are the people
who seemed to to be in possession of the
soul of New York at ten years later it
seemed to have passed on to Wall Street
and to the investment bankers who were
inevitably described in the business
pages as rock stars you know and and to
me I don't know that wasn't why a key
that wasn't to New York that I fell in
love with from afar and I would like to
think that you know that the New York
that I fell in love with hasn't
disappeared
Tyler or that it that is coming back
